title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines "Corporation" as The Howard Hughes Corporation and "Red Rock" as the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Nevada. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Clark County, Nevada, spans 195,780 acres and is protected under the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The area is depicted on the Red Rock Map, dated July 1, 2002, and overseen by the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected and enhanced for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to protect and enhance Red Rock. The Corporation owns much of the private land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is involved in development efforts. The Corporation owns a significant portion of private land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and is developing a large-scale master-planned community. This includes 1,071 acres of high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, which have not yet been acquired by the United States. Protecting this high-ground acreage is crucial for preserving the western Las Vegas Valley view-shed. The Corporation owns high-ground lands on Red Rock's eastern boundary, not yet acquired by the United States. They propose the US acquire the lands to preserve the view-shed and expand Red Rock. The Act aims to exchange lands between the United States and the Corporation to transfer high-ground lands to the US in exchange for other lands of equal value to the Corporation. It also seeks to protect and expand Red Rock as outlined by the Bureau of Land Management and fulfill the purposes of the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998. The Bureau of Land Management is considering actions depicted on the Red Rock Map to fulfill the purposes of the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 and the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990. The Bureau of Land Management is considering actions depicted on the Red Rock Map for the Red Rock Land Exchange. The Corporation offers approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States for incorporation into the NCA. In return, the Secretary will convey approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada. The Corporation will convey approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada. The private and Federal properties will be conveyed simultaneously. The Red Rock Map will be kept on file for public inspection in Nevada. The Secretary will keep the Red Rock Map available for public inspection in Nevada. Hazardous materials removal and remediation responsibility will be required for the Corporation as a condition of the conveyance. The Corporation must be responsible for removing and remediating hazardous materials on the property conveyed to the United States. A metes and bounds survey of the common boundary between the parcels of land to be conveyed must be provided within 90 days of the offer. Additionally, lands conveyed to Clark County must meet certain conditions. The Corporation must remove hazardous materials on the property conveyed to the United States. A metes and bounds survey of the common boundary between the parcels of land to be conveyed must be provided. Lands conveyed to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system. The lands conveyed to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system, reverting to the United States if used inconsistently. The lands conveyed to Clark County must be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system, reverting to the United States if used inconsistently. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the lands shown on the Red Rock Map as "Flood Control Detention Basin Lands" as part of Red Rock, in accordance with relevant laws. Upon acquisition of lands, the Secretary will make boundary adjustments as necessary. Upon acquisition of lands under the Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998, the Secretary will administer them as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws and create new maps reflecting boundary adjustments. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 requires the Secretary to administer acquired lands as part of Red Rock, create new maps reflecting boundary adjustments, and make them available for review at designated offices. Additionally, a conforming amendment expands the boundaries of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area. The boundaries of the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area are expanded to include additional areas as per the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area boundaries are expanded as per the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002. General provisions are outlined in Section 6. The Secretary must review an appraisal for a land exchange in Las Vegas within 90 days. Any difference in appraisal values will be reimbursed by the Corporation. The land exchange is subject to valid existing rights, and parties will succeed to the rights and obligations of the conveying party. The land exchange under this Act is subject to valid existing rights. Parties will succeed to the rights and obligations of the conveying party. Technical corrections can be made to the Red Rock Map. The Secretary shall withdraw affected lands if not already accomplished. The Secretary can withdraw Federal lands acquired or owned by the United States under this Act, subject to valid existing rights, and make technical corrections to the Red Rock Map. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
